ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: learned about multiple theories of development across dimensions like social development, cognitive/perceptual development, moral development, etc.
This was a very interesting course learning about development of Humans

This was my absolute favorite class this semester! I learned so much about development, and it was a great addition to my psychology major at Yale. It provides a lot of insight into developmental research (while also incorporating the history of studies within the field).
This course provided a great overview of the field of developmental psychology, drawing on studies from a diversity of sub fields to provide a complete picture of all that this field has to offer.

I learned immensely about development and how amazing children are. I came in thinking I knew most of what there was to know about child development, but this course opened my mind to so much more in the field.
Interesting info but hard to memorize for exam
I learnt more about how children develop and the various theories and experiments within the field of developmental science.
A better understanding of the mind and brain, through the lens of how it came to be as it is.
I learned about the most important theories of developmental psychology and the empirical studies that support or contradict these theories.

I learned how psychological notions and processes exhibited in adulthood develop and change from childhood to adolesence. The course equipped me with knowledge about various theories, hypotheses, and research findings related to the development of fundamental psychological concepts, such as  personality and cognition. This course enhanced my critical thinking and analytical skills, and deepened my appreciation for the complex processes involved in the development of psychological phenomena from childhood to adulthood.

Learned all about developmental psychology, from very granular neurological nuances to broader philosophical debates in the field. This course teaches you why we are the way we are, and answers questions that you subconsciously wonder about but don't fully understand. You learn what makes a 'good' study (not necessarily conclusive/accurate results) and how to use studies to advance your thinking.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: very structured class that was super easy to go along to! A lot of content was covered in this class 
Weakness: the first midterm review was handed out 2 days before fall break and then we had our exam (worth 40% of our grade) the Monday after break...

Strengths was the content in lectures was very interesting and I loved learning about the everyday applications. The professor also knew his stuff very well. Weaknesses was that I didn't feel incentivized to read the textbook or even go to class (although I did) because the only assignments were two tests. Although these tests were very reasonable.
Keil is too old to teach

Strengths: this course tied concepts together throughout the semester, allowing for intermittent review

Weaknesses: weekly summaries did not provide the best way for me to synthesize my knowledge, a more discussion-based approach with a larger character allowance would have been better
I enjoyed lecture and the readings, though at times it felt like we were taking in an immense amount of information during lecture.
Exam formats was really hard. But interesting concepts
Strengths: I think Prof Keil is a great lecturer and there's a lot of content to be learnt.
I liked the weekly summaries and the exams were scary but ultimately not too bad.

Strengths: Prof. Keil and Aaron were both great and so knowledgeable. They give you everything you need to succeed in the course. I really liked the exam format (get a list of ~35 essay questions to study, 5 of which appear on the exam), which essentially meant that if you studied well, there was no reason you wouldn't do well. It also made me feel like I knew that I was studying all of the important things, instead of getting lost in minutia.
Weaknesses: Some of the potential exam questions were super convoluted and badly worded, and made studying quite challenging and ridiculously time consuming.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, but understand that exams will be worth 80% of your grade!
Yes if you want to learn how humans develop and how children behavior can be explained

Absolutely! It's an amazing class to lay down the foundations for developmental psychology. It's a perfect class to build knowledge that can be applied to a variety of other psychology or child development classes.
Yes! I think the course is so interesting, from both the topic itself to the way it's taught.
Great class! Super digestible, even for non-psych majors. If you're even remotely interested in child development, you'll like this course!
Yes if needed for major
Yes I would. While content-heavy, I think there was a lot of interesting insights I gained about the mind of a child.

A crucial class to take if you want to understand the mind -- how do minds come to be the way they are? Are there many constraints or few? How does the environment shape aspects of ourselves? Is development stagelike or continuous? And so on... The professor is outstanding, though unfortunately has Parkinson's and will be retiring soon. His passion for developmental psychology is contagious. Generous grading, though you do need to study well for the exams.
This course had very interesting content and a good structure.
Yes! But only if you enjoy lectures about psychology

I would recommend this course to another student, especially if they were interested in how different psychological and cognitive processes develop from childhood to adolescence and translate in adults. This course explores various theories and research methodologies related to the manifestation and evolution of psychological processes and examines their complexities across different early life stages.
Absolutely. I think all of this information should be required learning. I am so happy to have taken this course.
